aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Report for Beech 200 in Morristown, New Jersey
The accident occurred in Morristown, New Jersey.
The accident occurred on January 4, 2020, at 12:15 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Beech 200.
The defining event was a runway excursion.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Executive/Corporate.
The accident number was ERA20CA139.
The aircraft registration was N200HF.
The Beech 200 aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were 9 people on board the aircraft.
No injuries were reported in the accident.
The pilot was flying in instrument meteorological conditions.
The pilot observed patchy fog over the approach end of the runway.
The pilot leveled off to avoid the fog.
The pilot landed the airplane with approximately 3,000 feet of runway remaining.
The total runway length was nearly 6,000 feet.
The pilot felt the airplane hydroplaning during landing.
The pilot used a combination of wheel braking and the beta range of the propellers to slow the aircraft.
The airplane overran the end of the runway.
The airplane entered grass and mud beyond the runway.
The nose landing gear collapsed during the runway excursion.
The airplane sustained substantial damage to the forward fuselage.
The pilot reported no pre-accident mechanical failures with the airplane.
The pilot reported no pre-accident mechanical malfunctions with the airplane.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be the airplane hydroplaning while landing on a wet runway.
The hydroplaning degraded the aircraft's braking capability.
The degraded braking capability resulted in a runway overrun.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined that the pilot's decision to land the airplane near the runway midpoint contributed to the accident.
The pilot's decision to land near the runway midpoint was due to fog over the approach end of the runway.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Morristown, New Jersey

## Date & Time: 
January 4, 2020, 12:15 Local

## Aircraft:
Beech 200

## Defining Event:
Runway excursion

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Executive/Corporate

## Accident Number:
ERA20CA139

## Registration:
N200HF

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
9 None

## Analysis

The pilot reported that, during the descent for an instrument approach in instrument meteorological conditions, he saw an area of patchy fog over the approach end of the runway and leveled off to avoid the fog. He landed the airplane with about 3,000 ft of the nearly 6,000-ft-long runway remaining and felt the airplane hydroplaning while using a combination of wheel braking and the beta range of the propellers. The airplane subsequently overran the end of the runway onto grass and mud, which resulted in the nose landing gear collapsing. The airplane sustained substantial damage to the forward fuselage. The pilot reported that there were no preaccident mechanical failures or malfunctions with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The airplane hydroplaning while landing on a wet runway, which degraded its braking capability and resulted in a runway overrun onto grass and mud and the nose landing gear collapsing. Contributing to the accident was the pilot's improper decision to land the airplane until it was near the runway midpoint due to fog over the approach end of the runway.

---
